Early this morning, bomb blasts tore through three London Underground trains and a double-decker bus.
The British police say at least 37 people were killed and hundreds more injured in the attacks.
The blast started at 8:51 in the morning, cutting through central London in the course of an hour.
The first emergency call sent police to a train near the Liverpool Street station.
The next was a train at King's Cross in north London.
A third blast tore through two trains at the Edgware Road station.
And finally, the bus at Tavistock Square in front of the offices of the British Medical Association.
Doctors in the building ran out to aid the wounded.
An eyewitness had this account of the bus attack.
Unidentified Man #1: I was coming down from King's Cross, down towards Euston, was in direct--to Tavistock Square, and the bus just blew up in front of my eyes.
I was on the telephone at the time.
Just a huge explosion, lots of smoke and debris raining down on me.
And when I looked up, the roof was gone and I just saw people jumping off the top of the bus and I hightailed it out of there, really.
Around the sites of the explosions, hotels and churches became makeshift hospitals.
Buses doubled for ambulances, as injured riders poured from the subway stations.
As the streets around the bombings cleared of all but emergency workers, Londoners in the rest of the city gathered around televisions, watching the news or quietly began the walk home on foot.
The city's public transportation system, which logs nearly eight and a half million passenger trips a day, was shut down.
Far north of the city in Gleneagles, Scotland, heads of the industrialized nations meeting for the G8 conference got the news.
Prime Minister Tony Blair left the conference by helicopter for London, but vowed to return tomorrow.
After arriving at Downing Street, Blair spoke to the nation.
